source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Specimens of each material and others of interest were exposed to the coolant inside perforated fuel cans replacing fuel pins in otherwise standard SGHWR fuel clusters

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: After irradiation, specimens were decrudded chemically and weight gains were measured

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Hydrogen pick-up was found by hot vacuum degassing

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Weight gains from irradiations up to 531 effective full-power days (EFPD) generally show a reasonably linear correlation with the fast fluence to which they have been exposed

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: There is a variation in corrosion rate between Zircaloy-2 materials of different histories; a quench treatment at the billet stage seems to be beneficial

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Metallographic examination of specimens and fuel cladding showed the presence of nodular corrosion after exposure in reactor in oxygenated water

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Hydrogen up-take by the specimens appears to be largely independent of corrosion weight gain making percentage pick-up figures of dubious value

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: The amounts of hydrogen taken-up, however, are small, representing less than 5 percent for many materials

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: Extrapolation of results to the expected full reactor life indicates that neither loss of section by corrosion nor hydrogen pick-up by the pressure tube should be lifelimiting

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk1
evidence_span: The SGHWR prototype was originally fitted with 102 pressure tubes in Zircaloy-2, produced by three different manufacturing routes, 4 tubes in Zircaloy-4 from two different routes, and 6 tubes in heat-treated Zr-2.5Nb

evidence_span: 4 tubes in Zircaloy-4 from two different routes

evidence_span: the initial light hydrogen content of some materials was reduced by isotopic dilution with deuterium, normally at 800°C, followed by vacuum degassing and rapid cooling

evidence_span: decrudding, the latter being a standard treatment of 30- min exposure in alkaline permanganate (3 percent potassium permanganate (KMnO4), 20 percent sodium hydroxide (NaOH) at = 95%, followed by refluxing for 30 min in 6 N HCl and washing in water

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk2
evidence_span: Hydrogen analyses were performed on portions of the specimens by hot vacuum extraction and simultaneous mass spectrometric determination

evidence_span: cold worked Zr-2.5Nb (Codes x and Y) was notable for spots, streaks, and patches

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk3
evidence_span: The accepted out-of-pile oxidation curve for Zircaloy-2 exposed at 280°C in pressurized water shows a linear post-transition rate of the order of 0.01 mg/dm²/d (mdd).

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk3
evidence_span: Some confirmation of this post-transition rate was obtained for specimens of main route Zircaloy-2 pressure tube and fuel cladding which were preoxidized at 330°C prior to exposure in the SGHWR steam drum. These settled down to give a mean extrapolated linear rate 0.0067 mdd in reasonable agreement with the accepted value.

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk3
evidence_span: The slope of the line is 8.89 mg/dm² per 10²⁰ neutrons (n)/cm²

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk3
evidence_span: for a nominal peak flux at the pressure tube of 3×10¹³ n/cm²/s an exposure of one day gives 0.0259×10²⁰ n/cm² so that the expected corrosion rate at this flux would be 0.23 mg/dm²/d

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk3
evidence_span: In the particular case of the fuel cladding preoxidized at 400°C, the slope of 13.65 mg/dm² per 10²⁰ n/cm² would indicate a corrosion rate at 3×10¹³ n/cm²/s flux of 0.35 mg/dm²/d

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk3
evidence_span: In the particular case of the fuel cladding preoxidized at 400°C, the slope of 13.65 mg/dm² per 10²⁰ n/cm² would indicate a corrosion rate at 3×10¹³ n/cm²/s flux of 0.35 mg/dm²/d

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk7
evidence_span: Results from the monitoring clusters up to 531 EFPD irradiation indicate that the extent of corrosion as measured by the weight gain generally follows the integrated fast neutron fluences

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk7
evidence_span: Material history has a important effect on in-pile corrosion rates and Zircaloy-2 production material has been shown to benefit from an α or α + β quench step

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk7
evidence_span: Study of fuel cladding specimens shows a steady rise in in-pile corrosion rate with increasing preoxidation temperature up to 400°C, the lowest rate being observed with pickled material

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk8
evidence_span: chemical attack by fission products is also involved

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk8
evidence_span: iodine, an abundant fission product, causes stress corrosion cracking of zirconium alloys

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk8
evidence_span: Liquid metal embrittlement (LME) of Zircaloy by cesium, which is an even more abundant fission product than iodine, also has been reported

source_id: STP633-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_3rd Volume_021_chunk8
evidence_span: cesium is generally much less aggressive than iodine toward Zircaloy
